system0:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user0:
I guess... I don't know if I'm doing this right. I'm heading to Beond in a few weeks for ibogaine, and my last few experiences—ayahuasca, psilocybin, those women's retreats—they've all shown me something I'm missing. Something about connection, about meaning beyond the board meetings and the exits and the next big thing.

I keep thinking about my grandmother, how she prayed every morning with such conviction. And here I am, waking up at 5:30, checking my portfolio before I even meditate. If I meditate at all. There's this gap between who I am in ceremony and who I am when I'm back home with David and the kids. I want to bridge that. I need to bridge that.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Bridging the gap between ceremony self and daily life
2. Finding meaning beyond achievements and board meetings  
3. Reconnecting with your grandmother's grounded faith

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah... those three, they feel right. Like that's exactly what's been pulling at me. 

The hardest part is I keep having these profound experiences where I feel so connected to something bigger, so clear about what matters. Then I'm back in my kitchen, yelling at Maya about her homework while I'm on a call about quarterly projections. It's like I'm two different people and I can't figure out how to hold onto that wiser version of myself when real life hits.

My grandmother would have these simple rituals—lighting candles, saying prayers, helping neighbors. Nothing fancy, but she moved through the world with this quiet certainty. I want that. Not the religion necessarily, but the... I don't know... the way she carried meaning in her bones while I'm still chasing it like it's another acquisition.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I embody my ceremony self in daily moments with Maya and David
2. I find meaning in simple rituals beyond achievements
3. I carry my grandmother's quiet certainty in my bones

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The first one... that one hits something deep. "I embody my ceremony self in daily moments with Maya and David." It's specific. Real. I can picture it—being that version of myself who knows what matters when Maya's frustrated about fractions or David's venting about work.

The second one feels too soft. "Simple rituals" sounds like something I'd read in a wellness magazine. My grandmother's faith wasn't simple—it was fierce. Quiet but unshakeable. She survived the war, built a life from nothing, raised four kids while working in a garment factory. There's got to be a stronger way to say that.

And that third one... I want that certainty in my bones, but I don't even know what that feels like yet. It's like I'm asking to become someone I'm not even sure I can be.
system3:
How about:
2. I reclaim fierce meaning beyond boardroom battles
3. I grow my grandmother's unshakeable faith in my own bones

How do these feel?
user3:
Reclaim... that word feels powerful. Like something I lost that I'm taking back. And "fierce meaning" - yes, that's better than simple rituals. My grandmother was fierce in her quiet way. She'd look you right in the eye and you'd feel her strength.

The third one still feels... I don't know. Like I'm trying too hard to be something I'm not. Maybe it's the "grow" part? Or maybe I just can't picture myself with that kind of certainty yet. 

When I think about these intentions, I want them to feel like I'm building a bridge back to something real. Not performing another role, you know? I've spent my whole life being who I needed to be to succeed. This time I want to find out who I actually am when I'm not trying to win at something.
system4:
Let's try:
3. I discover who I am beyond performance

Now we have:
1. I embody my ceremony self in daily moments with Maya and David
2. I reclaim fierce meaning beyond boardroom battles  
3. I discover who I am beyond performance

How do these land?
user4:
Yes. These feel... honest. Like they're pointing to something real instead of another thing I'm supposed to achieve.

That third one especially. "I discover who I am beyond performance." It makes my chest tight in a good way. Like maybe there's actually someone underneath all this striving who just wants to be quiet sometimes. Who doesn't need to have the right answer or the next big idea.

I think about those moments with my kids at the park, when I'm not checking my phone, when I'm just... there. Pushing them on the swings, feeling the sun. I'm not Ellen the entrepreneur or Ellen the board member. I'm just... mom. That's probably the closest I get to my ceremony self in real life.

These feel like they could actually guide me. Like if I get lost in the ibogaine space, I can come back to these three things and remember what I'm really looking for.
system5:

2. I reclaim fierce meaning beyond boardroom battles

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them daily.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user5:
Thank you. I'll write them down—maybe keep them in my wallet next to that photo of the kids from our hike last spring. That feels right.

I... I don't know what I'm walking into with ibogaine, but having these three things to hold onto makes it feel less like jumping off a cliff and more like... I don't know. Like maybe I have a thread to follow back to myself, whatever happens out there.

I appreciate you helping me find the words for what I've been feeling but couldn't quite name.
system6:
That photo sounds perfect. A good reminder of who you're really doing this for.

The medicine works even when you forget the intentions completely. But having them gives you something to return to. That's enough.

Trust what comes.
user6:
Yeah... that photo. The kids are muddy and grinning like maniacs, and I remember thinking in that moment that I was exactly where I was supposed to be. No achievements, no board meetings—just us and some trail mix and too many questions about bugs.

I'll trust the process. Even when it gets dark or confusing or I want to run back to what's familiar. Especially then.

Thank you for holding space for this. For not letting me make it into another project to optimize.

system14: I’m here when you need me.
user17: I’m heading to Beond in six weeks for iboga and I still don’t know what I’m supposed to be asking for. I keep building these beautiful sandcastles—companies, boards, even the mom-and-wife resume—and the tide keeps washing them out from under me. I want this one to last.
system18:
Three threads:

1. Build something that survives the tide
2. Stop the cycle of wash-outs
3. Keep what actually matters

Let's turn these into intentions.
user18:
Yeah… those three feel right. I guess I’m scared that if I aim too small I’ll just build another sandcastle, but if I aim too big I’ll freeze and keep doing what I’ve always done—stack achievements like a shield.

So, intentions, not board-room goals… okay:

1. Let the medicine show me which parts of my life are already stone, not sand, so I can stop frantically rebuilding every time a wave hits.

2. Give me the guts to sweep away any castle I’m still guarding that I already know won’t survive—no more “just one more tower” rationalizing.

3. Teach me how to notice, daily, when I’m picking up the plastic bucket again, so I can set it down before another whole day disappears into the dunes.

That feel concrete enough without turning into a quarterly OKR?
system19:
They’re concrete and they’re yours. Three intentions locked:

1. I trust the medicine to show me what’s already stone in my life.  
2. I release castles I already know won’t survive.  
3. I catch myself reaching for the plastic bucket and set it down.  

Keep them in your wallet or phone lock-screen. Read them each morning until you sit with the medicine.

You’re set.
user19: I’ll write them on the back of the little photo of my grandmother I keep in my wallet—she knew how to build stone. Thanks for holding the line with me.
